user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Application_Startup:
```c
void OS_Application_Startup(void)
{
    UtTest_EarlyInit();
    UT_BSP_Setup();

    /*
     * Wrap the UtTest_Setup() function in a UT segment called "SETUP"
     * This allows any assert calls to be used and recorded during setup
     */
    UtAssert_BeginTest("SETUP");
    UtTest_Setup();
    UtAssert_EndTest();
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_Application_Startup:
UtListHead_t *UtList_Create(uint32 NumTags)
{
    struct ListAllocator
    {
        UtListHead_t Head;
        UtListNode_t Tags[];
    };
    struct ListAllocator *NewList;
    UtListNode_t *        TagHead;
    size_t                ActualSize;
    uint32                i;

    ActualSize = sizeof(struct ListAllocator) + (sizeof(UtListNode_t) * NumTags);
    NewList    = (struct ListAllocator *)malloc(ActualSize);

    memset(NewList, 0, ActualSize);

    NewList->Head.Tags         = NewList->Tags;
    NewList->Head.NumberOfTags = NumTags;

    for (i = 0; i < NumTags; ++i)
    {
        TagHead       = &NewList->Head.Tags[i];
        TagHead->Tag  = i;
        TagHead->Next = TagHead;
        TagHead->Prev = TagHead;
    }

    return &NewList->Head;
}
...
uint32 OS_BSP_GetArgC(void)
{
    return OS_BSP_Global.ArgC;
}
...
char *const *OS_BSP_GetArgV(void)
{
    return OS_BSP_Global.ArgV;
}
...
void UT_BSP_DoText(uint8 MessageType, const char *OutputMessage)
{
    char   Buffer[16];
    size_t MsgLen;
    uint32 TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
    uint32 MsgEnabled   = BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity >> MessageType;

    if (MsgEnabled & 1)
    {
        UT_BSP_Lock();

        /* Determine if the message type warrants special treatment (color/highlight/etc). */
        switch (MessageType)
        {
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF:
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_RED | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_BLUE;
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN:
                OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1); /* add a bit of extra whitespace between tests */
                break;
            case UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS:
                TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT | OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_GREEN;
                break;
            default:
                break;
        }

        if (MsgEnabled <= 1)
        {
            TermModeBits = OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL;
        }

        snprintf(Buffer, sizeof(Buffer), "[%5s]", UtAssert_GetCaseTypeAbbrev(MessageType));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(TermModeBits);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(Buffer, strlen(Buffer));

        if (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL);
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(" ", 1);
        MsgLen = strlen(OutputMessage);
        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(OutputMessage, MsgLen);
        if (MsgLen == 0 || OutputMessage[MsgLen - 1] != '\n')
        {
            OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl("\n", 1);
        }

        UT_BSP_Unlock();
    }

    /*
     * If any ABORT (major failure) message is thrown,
     * then call a BSP-provided routine to stop the test and possibly dump a core
     */
    if (MessageType == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT)
    {
        OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl();
    }
}
...
void UT_BSP_Lock(void)
{
    OS_BSP_Lock_Impl();
}
...
void UT_BSP_Unlock(void)
{
    OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl();
}
...
void UT_BSP_StartTestSegment(uint32 SegmentNumber, const char *SegmentName)
{
    char ReportBuffer[128];

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer), "%02u %s", (unsigned int)SegmentNumber, SegmentName);
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN, ReportBuffer);
}
...
void UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport(const char *SegmentName, const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *TestCounters)
{
    char ReportBuffer[144];

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer),
             "%-22s ABORT::%-4u  WARN::%-4u  FLOW::%-4u  DEBUG::%-4u  N/A::%-4u",
             "",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FLOW],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_DEBUG],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_NA]);

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_INFO, ReportBuffer);

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer),
             "%02u %-20s TOTAL::%-4u  PASS::%-4u  FAIL::%-4u  MIR::%-4u  TSF::%-4u  TTF::%-4u",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->TestSegmentCount, SegmentName, (unsigned int)TestCounters->TotalTestCases,
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF]);

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_END, ReportBuffer);
}
...
void OS_ApplicationExit(int32 Status)
{
    if (Status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        exit(EXIT_SUCCESS);
    }
    else
    {
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I flagged fragments that can create or mask unreachable-code situations and therefore require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1:

- OS_Application_Startup: UtTest_Setup (or any code it calls) might perform a non-local exit (longjmp/exit/abort) or otherwise not return, which would make the subsequent UtAssert_EndTest() unreachable. The entire function should be reviewed to ensure no code is rendered unreachable by called routines.

- The malloc + memset sequence in UtList_Create: the code does not check the return value of malloc before dereferencing NewList in memset and subsequent member initializations. While this is primarily a reliability/defensive issue, it can lead to abnormal program termination; it should be checked for intended flow and whether any subsequent code becomes unreachable as a result.

- UT_BSP_DoText: the function calls OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl() when MessageType == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT. If OS_BSP_Shutdown_Impl is a non-returning routine (shutdown/abort/exit), this makes any code that would follow that call (in the same control flow) unreachable; also the call is outside the MsgEnabled branch (it is executed even when text output is suppressed), which may be surprising and deserves review.

- OS_ApplicationExit: both branches call exit(), a non-returning function. Any code placed after calls to OS_ApplicationExit (or after these calls within the function) would be unreachable. The use of exit should be checked for intended control flow and proper annotation/documentation (noreturn) if required by the project.

Why other fragments were not selected:
- Simple getters (OS_BSP_GetArgC, OS_BSP_GetArgV) and trivial forwarders (UT_BSP_Lock/Unlock, UT_BSP_StartTestSegment, UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport) are straightforward, contain no conditional branches or calls that would obviously make subsequent code unreachable, and thus do not present an immediate Rule 2.1 concern.
- Internal logic within UT_BSP_DoText (switch, formatting, console output) is reachable under the MsgEnabled condition; no obvious unreachable statements (e.g., code after unconditional return or after a call to a known-noreturn function) were found there beyond the abort/shutdown call already flagged.

Please investigate the flagged fragments to confirm whether any called routines are non-returning or whether control-flow makes any statements unreachable, and ensure appropriate handling/annotations per MISRA Rule 2.1.
